content.text: State the time taken for 30 drops to hit the ground
Calculate the average time between two drops hitting the ground
Explain why the student measures the time for 30 drops to hit the ground instead of measuring the time for one drop to hit the ground
A student uses a stopwatch to determine the time between two drops hitting the ground
He sets the stopwatch to zero. He starts the stopwatch when the first drop hits the ground
He stops the stopwatch after a further 30 drops have hit the ground
The reading on the stopwatch is recorded and shown in Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.1 shows that the drops get further apart as they get close to the ground
State why the drops get further apart
In another experiment the student determines the speed of a falling weight at different times. The speedâ€“time graph for his results is shown in Fig. 1.3
Calculate the distance fallen by the weight in the first 1.5 s
distance =   .........  m
Fig. 1.1 shows a water tank that is leaking. Drops of water fall from the tank at a constant rate
Fig. 1.1 (NOT to scale)
A student has an irregularly shaped piece of metal, a beaker of water and a measuring cylinder, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Describe how the student can accurately determine the volume of the piece of metal using the equipment provided
State the name of the instrument used to measure the mass
The volume of the piece of metal is \(20 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the metal. State the unit
density =   .........
The student measures the mass of the piece of metal. Its mass is \(146\mathrm{g}\)
Calculate the size and direction of the resultant horizontal force on the swimmer
size of resultant horizontal force =   .........  N
direction of resultant horizontal force =
State the name of the 110N force on the swimmer
Fig. 3.2 shows the horizontal forces acting on the swimmer as he moves forwards a short time later
Describe and explain the motion of the swimmer
Fig. 3.1 shows the horizontal forces acting on a swimmer
Another swimmer weighs \(700\mathrm{N}\). He stands on a diving board, as shown in Fig. 3.3
Calculate the moment of the swimmer's weight about point P
moment =   .........  Nm
Fig. 4.1 shows a metal triangle suspended from a thread
Complete the sentence. Choose the correct word or phrase from the box
The metal triangle will come to rest with its centre of mass directly ..................................... the point of suspension
A student finds the centre of mass of a shape made of thin card. Fig. 4.2 shows the equipment
Describe how the student finds the centre of mass of the card. Choose from these sentences
A A line is drawn on the card showing the position of the string
B A pin held in a clamp is put through the hole in the card
C The centre of mass is where the lines cross on the card
D The process is repeated using holes near the other two edges
Complete the flow chart. Write the letter for the correct sentence in each box
A small hole is made near one edge of the card
The plumbline is attached to the pin
Energy sources used to generate electricity are shown in the box
Which energy sources are non-renewable?
Draw a ring around **each** energy source that is non-renewable
The diagram shows a geothermal power station
Describe how the geothermal power station generates electricity
State the name of a liquid used in liquid-in-glass thermometers
The thermometer is calibrated using two fixed points
State the values of these fixed points
.........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\) and   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
Fig. 6.1 shows a liquid-in-glass thermometer
Complete the sentence. Choose a word from the box
Thermal (heat) energy moves through the metal can by ............................................
Describe how thermal energy is transferred throughout the water. Include your ideas about density changes
A student heats some water in a metal can, as shown in Fig. 6.2
Describe the arrangement, separation and motion of gas molecules
arrangement
separation
motion
On Fig. 7.2, continue the path of the smoke particle
State the term used to describe the movement of the smoke particle
The motion of smoke particles in air can be observed using a smoke cell and microscope. Fig. 7.1 shows the arrangement
Smoke is placed inside the glass smoke cell. Light enters from the side of the smoke cell
A student looks through the microscope. She sees tiny spots of light moving. Each spot of light is a smoke particle
Fig. 7.2 represents the path of a smoke particle seen in the eyepiece of the microscope
Fig. 7.2
All matter is made up of atoms and molecules
Which distance is the focal length of the lens? Tick **one** box
On Fig. 8.1, extend the **two** rays from the arrowhead on the object until both reach the position of the image
The object is moved a small distance **away** from the lens. State the effect, if any, this has on the position and size of the image
position
size
Fig. 8.1 is a partially completed ray diagram
The object is at O and its image is at I
At the start of the race, the sailors watch for the flash of light from the cannon
Suggest why the sailors watch for the flash of light rather than listen for the bang
One of the sailors is \(500\mathrm{m}\) from the cannon. She measures a time difference of 1.6 seconds between seeing the flash of light and hearing the bang
Calculate the speed of sound
speed of sound =   .........  m/s
The value of the speed of sound obtained in **(a)(ii)** is lower than expected
Suggest a reason for this difference
The race is held close to a part of the coast with high cliffs. A sailor hears a second bang shortly after the first bang
State the term for the second bang and explain how it is produced
term
explanation
A boat race starts on the sea, but close to land. Fig. 9.1 shows the boats at the start of the race
On the land, a cannon produces a loud bang to start the race. There is a flash of light at the same time as the bang
Draw the circuit symbol for a cell
State the term used for the arrangement of lamps in the circuit in Fig. 10.1
The switch is closed and the lamps light
State the name of the charged particles that are flowing through the wires
Compare Fig. 10.1 and Fig. 10.2. State **two** advantages of the type of circuit shown in Fig. 10.2 with the type of circuit shown in Fig. 10.1
The potential difference across the power source in Fig. 10.2 is 3.0 V. The combined resistance of the two lamps is \(12\Omega\). Calculate the size of the current in the circuit
current =   .........  A
Fig. 10.2 represents a different type of circuit
A circuit is made from two lamps, a cell and a switch, as shown in Fig. 10.1
Identify which of the following metals can be permanently magnetised. Place a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the box next to any correct metal
Two metal rods are thought to be permanent magnets. Describe the test you would carry out to confirm that both rods are permanent magnets
Describe how to make an electromagnet. You may draw a labelled diagram to help your answer
Suggest two factors that affect the strength of the magnetic field of an electromagnet
State the term given to the number 4, written in the nuclide notation
State the term given to the number 2, written in the nuclide notation
The nuclide notation for an \(\alpha\) -particle is
Use information from the graph in Fig. 12.1 to determine the half-life of the material. Clearly show how you used the graph to obtain your answer
half-life =   .........  minutes
Another radioactive material with the same half-life has an initial count rate of 600 counts/min. On Fig. 12.1 sketch the decay curve for this material
Fig. 12.1 shows the decay curve for a radioactive material
A radioactive substance decays by emitting an \(\alpha\) -particle
